Affixed: This equipment is worn and wielded in the main or off hand. While dual wielding with an affixed weapon, the other weapon does not need the Light property. Affixed weapons are donned or doffed as an action and cannot be disarmed. While worn, it can be equipped for free during your turn, and while not equipped, it remains attached to your body, leaving your hand open for other things.
Awkward: You do not have adequate training or experience to weird this weapon effectively, but you can still use it. You do not add your weapon skill bonus while rolling an attack or damage with this weapon.
Barbed: When this weapon is entangling your enemy, and the enemy succeeds on the check to escape from your grapple, that enemy takes your weapon’s damage.
Balanced: When this weapon rolls a 1 on any of its damage dice, you may reroll that dice but must use the new result. If you wield this weapon with two hands, you may reroll the damage dice if it is a 1 or a 2.
Brace: As an action you choose to Brace. On your turn, choose any targets you can see that are more than 20 feet away from you. If any of those targets move within your weapon’s reach before your next turn, as a reaction you can roll one melee attack against them with advantage. If the attack hits, treat the attack as a critical hit. While bracing, if you use a different reaction, or move or get moved, you are no longer bracing. A brace attack is not an opportunity attack.
Conceal: At the start of combat, if your passive Sleight of Hand is higher than your enemy’s passive perception, or as a bonus action make a Sleight of Hand check to beat this score, you can hide these weapons from your enemy. If hidden, the first attack made with it against a single unaware enemy is treated as attacking a Stunned creature, as your enemy wasn’t expecting your weapon. Once you use the weapon, you cannot hide it again, nor can you make any further surprise attacks with any conceal weapon during that same encounter.
Deflect: When struck by a melee weapon attack, you can use your reaction to deflect some damage you would receive. If wielding one Deflect weapon, you may roll your weapon’s standard damage dice (as defined by the weapon definition in this chapter), then subtract that total from the damage you would receive from a source you can see. If you are wielding a Deflect weapon with two hands, you can roll your weapon’s damage dice twice. If you are wielding two deflect weapons, you can roll both weapon’s deflect rolls and choose the highest result or you can choose to deflect another attack using your off hand weapon, as part of the same reaction. For the off hand deflect, you only deflect half of the damage on the dice roll.
Deflect does not interact with any other weapon property, such as keen or puncture; you simply roll your weapon’s damage dice normally.
Disarm: When you hit with a Disarm attack, you deal damage equal to your weapon damage modifier, and force your enemy to roll its choice of an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw. On a failure, it drops one held object of your choice, landing within 5ft of it in a direction of your choosing. If you have a free hand, you may come into possession of the disarmed object.

If your target is a category size larger than you or using a two-handed weapon, it gains advantage on this save, while enemies two size categories larger than you are immune to this attack from you. If it is smaller than you, it suffers disadvantage. If you land a critical hit with this attack, your weapon deals normal, non-critical damage in addition to forcing your enemy to roll the saving throw.
Double Ended: When you take the attack action, you can make one additional attack as an ability action using the damage listed - note that you do not add your weapon ability modifier for the offhand attack - if you are within 5 ft of your target and wielding your weapon with two hands.
Entangle: When you hit with an Entangle attack, you deal only your weapon ability modifier, and force the enemy to succeed on its choice of an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw or be Restrained by you. To escape, the creature must succeed a grapple check against your weapon DC, gaining advantage if it is a size category larger than you.

If you land a critical hit, your weapon deals normal, non-critical damage in addition to forcing your enemy to roll the saving throw. Creatures two size categories larger than you are immune to Entangle attacks from you.

While you are holding the weapon entangling your target, your weapon attacks against it automatically hit, but only deal damage equal to your weapon ability modifier. You can release an entangled enemy at any time. If you drop the weapon, the creature is immediately free.
Heavy: Category size Small creatures suffer disadvantage to attack rolls and Tiny and smaller cannot wield this weapon.
Hipshot: This ranged weapon is extremely nimble and maneuverable. When you make a ranged weapon attack, you ignore the disadvantage from a hostile creature within 5ft of you.
Keen: This weapon is extraordinarily sharp or devastatingly accurate. When you score a critical hit with this weapon, add an additional damage dice to the weapon damage dice rolled. The added damage dice is not doubled from a critical hit.
Knockback: When you hit with a knockback attack, you deal only your weapon ability modifier, and your enemy must succeed on its choice of an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw or be pushed 5 feet in a direction of your choosing. If you land a critical hit, your weapon deals normal, non-critical damage in addition to forcing your enemy to roll the saving throw. Creatures a size category larger than you gain advantage on this save. Creatures two sizes larger than you are immune to being pushed this way.
Light: In order to dual wield two weapons, both weapons you wield must have this property. You can make an attack with your off-hand weapon as a bonus action, but don’t add any ability modifier to damage. There is no requirement that your off hand weapon be melee in order to dual wield.
Lunge: If you use an attack action, you can use 5ft of movement to attack a foe up to 5ft further than normal. Each attack which uses this property costs 5ft of movement. In order to use the lunge property, there must be clear ground in the direction of your lunge. You cannot lunge if an enemy or obstacle is directly in front of you.
Melee: Melee weapons make a melee weapon attack at a target up to 5ft away.
Natural: A natural weapon is one which is part of a creature’s anatomy, such as teeth and claws. To have a natural weapon, you must either become a creature for which a natural weapon is listed in its stat block, or have a racial ability which allows you to make an attack using claws, teeth, etc in place of an unarmed attack. Natural weapons cannot be removed, disarmed, or broken in any way and are always equipped.
Nimble: When you make an attack against a creature that you are restraining or that you are restrained by, or while prone, you gain advantage to the roll. This advantage does not cancel the disadvantage that may be appled by restraining or being restrained. It replaces it.
One Handed: This weapon requires only one hand to wield properly.
Penetrate: When you attack an enemy wearing armor, you ignore half of their armor bonus to their Armor Class.
Puncture: These piercing weapons deal significantly more damage if they hit a vital weak spot in the enemy. When you roll a maximum value with any of your weapon’s damage dice, you can roll that dice again and add the result to the total damage dealt. This can keep happening as many times as you roll maximum values on damage dice, even on the new rolls.
Ranged: Ranged weapons make a ranged weapon attack within range. It must be loaded with ammunition to make an attack. The ranged numbers list its normal and maximum range. When attacking enemies beyond the normal range or with an enemy within 5ft of you, you suffer disadvantage for that attack. A ranged weapon cannot attack targets beyond its maximum range.
Reach: This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you make a melee weapon attack, as well as for determining your reach for opportunity attacks with it. Note that if there is a creature between you and your enemy within reach, your enemy has cover. Reach cannot be used to extend the range of a Double Ended attack.
Reload: Some ranged weapons take a time to reload, expressed in types of game actions. These game actions represent the time it takes to reset a weapon and prime it for another attack. From fastest to slowest, these are; free, reaction, ability, attack, action.
Reload weapons require two hands to reload unless otherwise stated. If dual wielding with a Reload weapon, one item must be sheathed or dropped to Reload.
Reloading as an action means that you must use your action in order to reload your weapon.

Reloading as attack means you use an attack action and one of your main hand attacks is used to reload. If you have 3 attacks, you attack once, use your second attack to reload, then attack again. Note that you must use either an attack or an action to reload, and if you do not wish to attack, then reloading your weapon takes an action.
Reloading as an ability means that your must use you ability action to reload your weapon.
Likewise, reloading as a reaction means that you must use your reaction to reload your weapon.
Reload free has no action economy cost and reloads as quickly as a bow. The only detriment is that a Reload weapon still takes two hands to reload.
You must always reload your weapon before using it for a ranged weapon attack again. If your weapon is empty at the end of your turn, it must be reloaded before you can use it again.
You have the choice of reloading your weapon with any of the options that are slower.
Thrown: Thrown weapons are used to make a ranged weapon attack by throwing them at the enemy, dealing their melee damage on hit unless a different damage value is listed after the Thrown weapon property.
You may draw and throw a weapon as part of the attack. If you throw a weapon without the Thrown property, the weapon is treated as an improvised weapon and may only cause a small amount of damage.
Trip: When you hit with a trip attack, you deal only your weapon ability modifier in damage on hit, and your enemy must succeed on its choice of an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw or be knocked prone. If you land a critical hit, your weapon deals normal, non-critical damage in addition to forcing your enemy to roll the saving throw. Enemies a size category larger than you gain advantage on this save. Enemies two size categories larger than you are immune to being tripped in this way.
Two Handed: This weapon requires two hands to use when you attack with it. You can’t use only one hand to attack with a two handed weapon.
Versatile: This weapon may be used with one or two hands and you can switch between them at any time. When used with two hands, you use the damage dice listed in parentheses.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Gauntlet
Ambush Weapons.Description: Spiked or weighted knuckles worn as a glove or held in hand. The hand with the gauntlet cannot be used to wield other equipment.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: When hit with a melee attack, as a reaction before the damage, you can attempt a disarm attack. If your enemy fails, you disarm them and take no damage.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Hidden Blade
Ambush Weapons.Description: A mechanical means to instantly deploy a piercing dagger from under the wrist built into a bracer. The master takes full advantage of a surprise attack, ending a life in an instant.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: Surprised creatures take maximum damage from this weapon.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Interceptor
Ambush Weapons.Description: A generic term for clothing used to deflect, such as a thick wool cloak, silk scarf, or wide brimmed hat. While you may wear an interceptor, it must be equipped to be used but gives you +1 weapon AC when equipped. The master can catch missile weapons in flight, even protecting an ally.

Properties: You cannot wield an intercepter without training

Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: Your deflect can be used against ranged weapon attacks. When a creature you can see attacks a target within 5 ft of you (yourself included) you can use your reaction to decrease the damage taken.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Katar
Ambush Weapons.Description: A wide, leaf shaped blade mounted in line with the fist at the end of an H shaped handle. The katar is a unique punch weapon, and the master’s speed and precision is unmatched.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit you can make an additional attack as part of this same action. These extra attacks can also activate this ability but only on a natural 20.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Knuckle Axe
Ambush Weapons.Description: The knuckle axe resembles an axe head with no handle, and either 4 finger holes or a curved handle to rest inside a closed fist. Masters with knuckle axes slash through soft targets much like a real axe, attacking two targets at once.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit or reduce a target to 0hp you may make an additional melee attack to another creature adjacent to you as part of the same action.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Punch Dagger
Ambush Weapons.Description: A small knife attached to a horizontal handle that projects out from the fist when held. It can be easily deployed in a swift punching motion allowing a master true speed and precision unmatched.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: You have advantage on attacks made outside of your turn. Additionally, if this weapon is in your off hand, you may make an opportunity attack with your main hand and this weapon.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Side Baton
Ambush Weapons.Description: Often called a Tonfa, Riot Baton, or Arm Club, this defensive weapon is designed to deflect attacks with the forearm. It is a stout club with a perpendicular handle attached a third of the way down the length, allowing it to be swung out for a swipe, or extend the reach of a thrust. A master uses the handle as a hook just effectively as an axe and maximizes the defensive properties of this weapon.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: You gain +1 weapon AC. Your deflect roll is d10, rather than d8.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Unarmed Strike
Ambush Weapons.Description: Untrained unarmed strikes are simple punches while training teaches proper punches and kicks. However, a real master of unarmed strikes is as well trained as a traditional monk.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: You may make an Unarmed strike as an off hand attack even if you’re wielding a weapon without the light property. You may spend an ability action to shove or perform a disarm attack.

Ambush Weapons.Name: Whip Dagger
Ambush Weapons.Description: A dagger with a ring pommel at the end of a silk ribbon. The weapon can be used like a dagger in hand to attack creatures up to 5ft away, or swung about the end of the ribbon to attack creatures up to 10ft away. A master can perform the Scorpion Pull, an ability to impale a target and pull them closer with the attached ribbon.
Ambush Weapons.Master Ability: When your attack is successful, as an ability action, you can choose to force the enemy to succeed on an Athletics check or be pulled up to 10ft toward you. You may only do this if your target is no more than 1 size category larger than you.

Axes.Name: Battle Axe
Axes.Description: An axe about 2ft-3ft in length, with a longer beard designed for a wider slashing wound. This weapon is large enough to use with two hands for more powerful strikes, yet nimble enough to be used in one hand. Masters with the battle axe are stout and reliable with their bit, and throw the axe with a large overhand pitch with both hands at the base of the handle.
Axes.Master Ability: You may reroll any result of 1 or 2 on any damage die caused by this weapon. If you are wielding the Battle Axe with two hands. it gains Thrown d12 (20/60).

Axes.Name: Greataxe
Axes.Description: The classic barbarian axe, but which also includes more historical versions such as the bardiche, voulge, or Dane axe. The greataxe has incredible potential for damage, and the master greataxe wielder fells even the stoutest of foes with reliability not seen in many other weapon styles.
Axes.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit you can roll all damage twice and take the better result.

Axes.Name: Halberd
Axes.Description: An axe blade topped with a spike mounted on an 8ft long shaft, with a hook on the back side of the axe blade for pulling mounted combatants from the saddle. With some experience, a halberd can be used to perform a trip against mounted foes to pull them from the saddle to a prone position, and the master has conquered this maneuver.
Axes.Master Ability: Your trip attacks impose disadvantage to checks made to resist them.

Axes.Name: Handaxe
Axes.Description: An incredibly versatile weapon and tool, the hand axe can be thrown, or used in melee, and can be used to trip your foe, and the master binds and disarms with lightning efficiency. If you have a handaxe on your person, you may gain advantage on survival checks where the handaxe can be used to help, such as cutting firewood or putting up tents.
Axes.Master Ability: If you miss with a disarm attack, you may reroll but must take the new result.

Axes.Name: Hook Sword
Axes.Description:
An exotic weapon made famous by the northern Chinese masters; a shortsword length weapon in which the tip forms a prominent hook, and which the knuckle guard features a crescent shaped blade. A hook sword can easily catch weapons and limbs, giving it superior control over an enemy’s movements.
The master can also join two hook swords together for a unique means of trapping and binding enemies, as well as striking further by forming a makeshift flail; letting go of one hook sword and swinging it by the hook of the other sword. Hooking the swords together, or unhooking and wielding them separately can be taken as part of an attack. When you hook two hook swords together, your weapon gains Reach and loses Light. While wielded in this way, your hook swords count as one weapon instead of dual wielding two weapons.
Axes.Master Ability: When you are hit with a melee weapon attack, as a reaction, you can make a disarm or entangle attack against that enemy.

Axes.Name: Khopesh
Axes.Description: This hybrid axe and sword was made famous by ancient Egyptians. It is a sword built with a large crescent shaped protrusion about one third from the tip, and a hooked tip, forming a sort of question mark shape. It acts similarly to a handaxe, but is lighter and can more reliably cut with a larger surface area. A Master with the Khopesh has learned to use the hooked point to hamstring enemies with ease.
Axes.Master Ability: If you hit with a trip attack, your enemy’s speed is reduced by 10ft until the end of their next turn. While they have this penalty, they suffer disadvantage to Athletic checks.

Axes.Name: Poleaxe
Axes.Description: An infantry weapon designed for use against armored foes, characterized by an axe on one side and a hammer on the other, tipped with a dagger-like spike from the top. It is typically on a 6 ft haft, shod with iron to protect it from damage. Though not long enough for a reach weapon, its style resembles that of a quarterstaff and axe combined. A master uses the weapon’s iron shodding more actively, blocking attacks that would normally chop through the wood shaft.
Axes.Master Ability: You gain +1 weapon AC and you may add your weapon ability bonus to deflect rolls.

Axes.Name: Tomahawk
Axes.Description:
Also called a fransisca, this small axe features a slimmer blade more balanced for throwing, and an opposing spike or small hammer so both sides of the weapon were dangerous in flight.
Tomahawks are balanced for throwing further distances than any other axe, and the master throws them with great force, using the hammer or spike’s weight to drive the thinner axe head deeper into a target and throw them off balance or strike their arm mid swing.
Axes.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit, your enemy has disadvantage on its next attack roll.

Bludgeons.Name: Bar Mace
Bludgeons.Description: A stout, arm length iron bar lined with spikes or flanges, more able to utilize prying leverage to deal with armored foes. Designed for low skilled military soldiers, a master uses the many angles to pry weapons from the enemy’s hands.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, you can choose to deal damage equal to your weapon ability modifier, but force your enemy to suffer disadvantage to attacks. At the end of their turn they can roll a Constitution check, ending this penalty on success.

Bludgeons.Name: Bo Staff
Bludgeons.Description: The Japanese bo is a much smaller and thinner version of the quarterstaff, and the result is a much faster fighting style, devoted to quick successive strikes and acrobatic lunges. The master can turn one opening into a strike for two and has learned to deflect even powerful blows with a simple wooden stick.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: If you have the Extra Attack feature, you may make two attacks instead of one when you use this weapon’s Double Ended property or when you make an opportunity attack.

Bludgeons.Name: Flanged Mace
Bludgeons.Description: A metal head with bladed protrusions, attached to a simple shaft designed specifically to hammer and shred armor. Masters punch through any armor to damage foes with ease.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: Your penetrate ignores 3/4 of enemies armor bonus to their Armor Class, instead of 1/2

Bludgeons.Name: Great Club
Bludgeons.Description: A simple, heavy, two-handed club, though it can be refined like the Japanese Tetsubo. A master of the greatclub can render a weapon nearly useless by smashing it bent or broken.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit, your enemy must succeed on a Reflex check, or their mundane weapon suffers a permanent disadvantage on attack rolls until it is repaired

Bludgeons.Name: Heavy Club
Bludgeons.Description: A larger mass weapon, much like a bat or ball mace. A master can target the foe’s head more easily, disorienting and disabling their foes with a wound-up swing for the fences.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit, your enemy must succeed on a Constitution check or suffer disadvantage to all attacks and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

Bludgeons.Name: Light Club
Bludgeons.Description: A simple sap or a metal bar, many clubs used for combat are designed to be thrown. Some light clubs are designed for policing, intended to be less-than-lethal, while others can be shorn in spikes or sharpened rings with a broad spiked tip. A master is extremely accurate at a foe’s head to knock them off balance.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, your foe must succeed on a Constitution check or suffer disadvantage to its Fortitude and Wisdom based ability checks until the end of your next turn.

Bludgeons.Name: Mallet
Bludgeons.Description: Typically a crafter’s tool, consisting of a shallow cylinder on a short handle. The lighter, faster bludgeon takes unique opportunities that other bludgeons would miss. A master uses the lightness of a mallet for a quick strike that sends the enemy reeling.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: If you choose the attack action, as a bonus action, you can make a shove attempt which, if successful, deals this weapon’s damage.

Bludgeons.Name: Morningstar
Bludgeons.Description: An infantry weapon in the form of a thick wooden shaft up to 8 feet in length, slightly fluted toward the top, with a spiked head and topped with a stout iron spike. This reach weapon gives infantry an advantage against armored opponents without needing to learn advanced techniques, enabling simple militias to protect themselves from armor. A master with a morning star can absolutely ruin armor, rendering it less effective for its wearer.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit, your target’s armor bonus to their AC is reduced by 1. This effect can stack until the target has no armor bonus to their AC, and is not removed until the armor has been repaired.

Bludgeons.Name: Quarterstaff
Bludgeons.Description: A quarterstaff is a heavier, thicker staff, meant for more weight and power in blocking than quick strikes in succession. Sometimes shod in iron, this staff provides increased protection for the master, able to use its shodding and length to provide a more stable means of defense.
Bludgeons.Master Ability: You gain +1 weapon AC. Additionally, when you attack a foe that is more than 5ft away from you, your weapon damage becomes 1d10

Bows and Slings.Name: Bladed Bow
Bows and Slings.Description: Two curved blades affixed to longbow length limbs. Though not nearly as stout as a quarterstaff due to the flexibility of the bow itself, it is nonetheless an effective way to fight the close enemy. The bladed bow is very specialized and requires dedicated training to be anything but clumsy but in the hands of a master, the blade bow can protect a retreat as easily as it can press a melee attack.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: While holding this weapon, your movement does not incur opportunity attacks.

Bows and Slings.Name: Compound Bow
Bows and Slings.Description: About the size of a shortbow, but has two pulleys on the limbs which allow the user to load exponentially more force. Because of the added mechanical aspect, loading is a bit slower than loading other bows, but its stopping power punches like a crossbow. A master can overdraw the pulleys to punch through targets like a crossbow.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, you deal normal damage to your primary target and weapon damage to one other target in a straight line from you that intersects your first target, as long as your attack roll would hit your second target’s AC as well.

Bows and Slings.Name: Greatbow
Bows and Slings.Description: Much taller and stouter than the longbow, easily reaching 6ft-8ft in length and as thick as a quarterstaff. It launches specialized great arrows that are similar in size to a javelin. Due to its size, javelins and ballista bolts can be used as ammunition, but with disadvantage to the attack roll. Greatbow masters can overdraw the stout poundage, sending enemies flying back.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, you also force your target to save against knockback. All creatures that are flying have disadvantage on this save.

Bows and Slings.Name: Longbow
Bows and Slings.Description: A larger bow than the shortbow, consisting of 5ft-6ft limbs, thick sinew cording bowstring, and a longer powerstroke. Perhaps a bit cumbersome in close combat and atop a mount, even so, a master archer steadies their aim in any situation, ignoring distractions which may impede accuracy.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: If you suffer disadvantage for any reason, you can use your ability action to negate your disadvantage until the end of your turn. You no longer suffer disadvantage to attacks made beyond normal range.

Bows and Slings.Name: Recurve Bow
Bows and Slings.Description: Usually shorter, in the 3ft-4ft range, but with a longer power stroke than a shortbow of its size. Each limb curves away from the wielder at its ends, effectively loading twice the elastic power into the arrow. Due to the shorter overall size but higher draw, the master can load an extra arrow into the recurve and attack two different targets.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: You can loose two arrows at once with the same power. Once on each of your turns when you make a recurve attack, you can make another recurve attack against a different creature that is within 5 feet of the original target and within normal range.

Bows and Slings.Name: Shortbow
Bows and Slings.Description: A simple bow about 3ft in length, more suited to close combat, as its smaller size lends itself to agile movement and quick targeting on either side of the body. Masters with the shortbow can make snap shots as quickly as any swordsman reacts to an opening.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: You may use your ability action to make a ranged attack even if you used your action for something else.

Bows and Slings.Name: Sling
Bows and Slings.Description: A simple leather cup swung about the body to release a stone with circular momentum. You can launch anything that can fit in the cup; bombs, potions, poisons, even rounded stones, but do so with -1 to the attack. You may also put something into the sling and make a melee attack with it, swinging the weapon like a flail. A master maximizes their power in the throw, and can disable and disorient an enemy with precise shots to the head.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, the target must succeed on a Constitution check or suffer disadvantage to attacks until the end of its next turn.

Bows and Slings.Name: Wrist Shot
Bows and Slings.Description: Instead of gathering circular momentum, this slingshot uses elastic material to launch anything a sling can without the penalty. A wrist shot is a favorite of smaller folk, more easily able to conceal the weapon and able to make use of ranged attacks with smaller arms and generally weaker stature. Masters with wrist shots can target weak points and make it easier for their allies to land critical blows.
Bows and Slings.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, your enemy loses its reaction until the start of its next turn.

Combat Blades.Name: Broadsword
Combat Blades.Description: True broadswords have a wider blade to add power to the cut, and often perform more like an axe in the strike. Examples include the messer, cleaver sword, or Chinese dadao. A master strikes through soft targets, driving their momentum to other targets.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit or reduce a target to 0 hit points, you can make another attack to another target within 5ft, as part of the same action. This effect can happen multiple times as long as the criteria are met.

Combat Blades.Name: Falchion
Combat Blades.Description: Descended from the broadsword, the cusped tip and straight blade was a later period design but iconic in appearance, and this two handed version represents the pinnacle of its design. A master maximizes the falchion’s cutting power, striking soft targets with critical accuracy.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: If your attack is at least 5 higher than your target’s AC, your attack is automatically a critical hit

Combat Blades.Name: Greatsword
Combat Blades.Description: Often as tall as its wielder, spanning in the 5ft-6ft range with a 2ft handle and a lengthy, wide blade. The long blade, lengthy handle, and added weight make the greatsword one of the most damaging melee weapons in use, and can easily dispatch larger targets with ease. A master finds the greatest weapon to use against a large enemy is the greatsword.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: Against category size Large and larger targets, your damage is 2d12, instead of 2d10.

Combat Blades.Name: Katana
Combat Blades.Description: A single edged blade, slightly curved with a minimal guard and a long handle. The longer handle and curved edge provide greater leverage for more effective deflections. A master deflects even powerful blows with ease.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: While wielding a katana with one hand, you may add your weapon ability modifier to deflect rolls. While wielding with two hands, your deflect dice becomes 2d10.

Combat Blades.Name: Longsword
Combat Blades.Description: A multipurpose sword with a wide guard for dueling, heavy pommel for balance, and a fine, rapier point. Generally a hand and a half handle, this sword is favored by spellblades for its ease of use in one hand or two. Masters become devastatingly accurate, standing up to even master duelists.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: Your critical hit range extends by 1 (19-20 if no other modifiers) and while wielding with two hands your critical hit range extends by 2 (18-20 if no other modifiers).

Combat Blades.Name: Montante
Combat Blades.Description: A long greatsword made famous by western Europeans, similar to a polearm in reach and technique thanks to a handle above the guard called a ricasso. The master has learned the famous protection technique, keeping an ally safe with expert application of refined angles and parries.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: On your turn, you can use your reaction to enter a protective stance. Until the start of your next turn, all attacks against allies within your reach suffer disadvantage.

Combat Blades.Name: Odachi
Combat Blades.Description: The famous horse killer blade from late period Japan, the odachi is the greatsword of the east. Its curved cutting edge and huge handle give the master a perfect balance of defense and offense missing from western styles.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: You deal one additional damage die to your target if you attack a different target than your previous attack.

Combat Blades.Name: Scimitar
Combat Blades.Description: A single-handed curved sword, with generally more weight in the blade than the pommel. The added agility and pommel weight give the master a sweeping, mobile fighting style that benefits from flowing movement over rigid stance.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: If you travel at least 20 ft or are mounted, your next attack deals an additional 1d8 damage.

Combat Blades.Name: Short Glaive
Combat Blades.Description: A glaive weapon with a shorter handle, usually in the range of length of a greatsword, but much lighter as the metal blade is smaller and more than half of the weapon is wooden haft. A short glaive is favored among elven armies as an effective long weapon that is both heavy hitting and light enough to use with finesse. Masters are lightning fast, quickly taking advantage of a miss to make an offensive opening.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: If an enemy you can see misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to make an attack with advantage against that enemy.

Combat Blades.Name: War Sword
Combat Blades.Description: Child of the Longsword and Greatsword, this sword’s length lies between the two, combining both styles. A master deals greater damage against larger targets like the Greatsword, with deft precision of the tip much like a Longsword.
Combat Blades.Master Ability: Your critical hit range is 19-20 while wielding with two hands, unless it is already larger. Against category size Large and larger enemies, your damage is 2d8(2d10) instead of d12(2d8).

Crossbows.Name: Blowgun
Crossbows.Description: A tube used to launch a needle dart with your breath. The dart is small and silent, and if you make an attack from stealth and miss, your location is not revealed. A master uses the art of the flying viper, shooting two darts at once and reloading with a single hand.
Crossbows.Master Ability: You can load two darts and shoot two with the same attack roll at the same target or to two targets that are within 5 feet of one another. Each dart can deliver a poison or other payload, and this weapon’s Keen property applies to any poison it delivers. Apply your weapon ability modifier to only one dart for damage.

Crossbows.Name: Hand Crossbow
Crossbows.Description: A hand drawn bow on a pistol grip, these prods are weaker than other crossbows, but the drawstring can be pulled back without mechanical assistance. A master reloads one-handed, using the bolt case to draw and load in one motion.
Crossbows.Master Ability: Can be reloaded with one hand. As an ability action, you can make an off-hand attack if you haven’t used it for an attack or held your action for an attack.

Crossbows.Name: Heavy Crossbow
Crossbows.Description: A large crossbow with steel prods, loading over a thousand pounds of force. A master arbalist has become deadly accurate with their bolt, maximizing their sniper potential.
Crossbows.Master Ability: Every 5 more you roll over your target’s AC, you add another weapon damage die. These additional dice are unaffected by a critical hit.

Crossbows.Name: Hidden Crossbow
Crossbows.Description: This wrist-mount is similar to a hidden blade, deploying in secret with one hand. The small mechanism can be pulled back by hooking it onto the needle case to reload one-handed. The master can shoot in melee at the slightest distraction.
Crossbows.Master Ability: If an enemy misses you with an attack, you can use your reaction to make a ranged attack against it.

Crossbows.Name: Light Crossbow
Crossbows.Description: A simple wooden crossbow drawn by pulling a lever. A master can move and shoot reflexively at moving targets.
Crossbows.Master Ability: You may use your reaction to make a ranged opportunity attack when an enemy enters or exits a 10ft radius around you.

Crossbows.Name: Mauler
Crossbows.Description:
Two bows mounted in an X shape to a tiller which holds three bolts. Even with four prods, the bolts fly with less power than a hand crossbow and don’t group well at distance, but have incredible stopping power up close. Masters group the bolts at weak points with devastating effect.
Because the bolts spread over distance, the damage is only 1d4+1 on medium or smaller size targets outside normal range, as only the top bolt is on target. All three bolts hit Large and larger creatures at any range.
Crossbows.Master Ability: If you roll another die with the Puncture property, roll 2d4 instead of 1d4.

Crossbows.Name: Portable Ballista
Crossbows.Description:
This small siege weapon is slow to reload with an enormous crannequin but the punch is worth the wait. Masters use flanking surfaces to pin a target with the launched javelin.
A deployable stand can be purchased for 150g. As an action, you mount the ballista to the stand. While mounted, its reload is an object interaction, but you cannot move it until you use another action to unmount it.
Crossbows.Master Ability: Your Entangle attacks add the restrained condition if successful, as you pin your target to surrounding terrain features.

Crossbows.Name: Repeating Crossbow
Crossbows.Description: Repeaters have a weaker draw strength to allow the user to draw with one hand by pulling a lever along the bottom much like a modern shotgun. It holds 6 bolts and once depleted, you must spend an action to refill the magazine. The master has learned to shoot as they pull the reload lever, dumping shots into a target with speed.
Crossbows.Master Ability: You may use your ability action as an attack action if you do not move on your turn.

Crossbows.Name: Spinner
Crossbows.Description: This gnomish invention launches discus blades with internal mechanisms instead of prods. It holds ten blades, reloading for free by pulling the level located at the back of the weapon. When depleted, you must spend an action to reload ten more. Masters can attack several targets at once by expertly planning their ricochet path.
Crossbows.Master Ability: As an action, you can choose up to 5 distinct targets, within 10ft of your first target to all be the target of a single attack roll. Roll damage separately for each target you hit.

Dueling Blades.Name: Dagger
Dueling Blades.Description: Any forearm length blade can be called a dagger, and there are as many designs as there are cultures in existence. The master can make lightning fast attacks even while they focus their attention elsewhere.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: As an ability action, you can make an off-hand attack if you haven’t used it for an attack or held your action for an attack.

Dueling Blades.Name: Kukri
Dueling Blades.Description: A thick, hooked blade with a cutting edge on the inside, performing more like a handaxe than a dagger. The wing shape flies somewhat like a boomerang, and the master uses its forward curve to hamstring enemies.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: When you hit with a trip attack, your target’s speed is reduced by 10ft. It may attempt a Constitution check at the end of its turn, ending the effect on success.

Dueling Blades.Name: Rapier
Dueling Blades.Description: A thin, tapered sword with a wide guard and extra weight in the handle for maximum control with the tip, prized as the pinnacle of finesse. Rapier masters are unmatched duelists with perfect reach and riposte.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: If you are wielding only a rapier, you can add d4 to your damage rolls. If you are dual wielding a light weapon, instead add +1 to weapon AC.

Dueling Blades.Name: Saber
Dueling Blades.Description: Slightly curved, single-edged, one-handed weapons often with a basket hilt, allowing expert deflections off the curve. The master’s defensive capabilities with the saber are unmatched among dueling blades.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: If you are wielding a single saber, you may add d4 to your deflect rolls. While wielding two sabers, if you reduce an enemy’s damage to 0, you gain the use of your reaction back.

Dueling Blades.Name: Sai
Dueling Blades.Description: A dagger sized weapon made famous in Okinawa, consisting of a sharpened metal rod with two forward swept prongs as a guard, making it easy to block and trap enemy weapons. The master parries and disarms in an instant with the prongs.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: You gain +1 weapon AC. If an enemy misses you with a melee attack, as a reaction you can force them to succeed on a saving throw or drop the weapon.

Dueling Blades.Name: Shortsword
Dueling Blades.Description: Swords between 2ft-3ft in length with as many different designs as there are cultures. Their wide and varied designs mean that a master can find the perfect form for their style.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: The balanced property applies to attachers. If you have advantage, you can roll damage and attachers twice and use the better result.

Dueling Blades.Name: Sickle
Dueling Blades.Description: A crescent-shaped blade derived from a farming tool with the cutting edge on the inside. A master with the sickle has learned to grab and hamstring with the reaping curve.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: When you hit with an entangle or trip attack, you deal full weapon damage and your enemy suffers -10ft to its speed until it succeeds on a Constitution check at the end of its turn.

Dueling Blades.Name: Smallsword
Dueling Blades.Description: A needle-like blade with a narrow profile and a fine tip for fitting between plates of armor, often given a dome shaped guard to protect the hands while thrusting. The master has such control and poise that any distraction or detriment can be ignored with enough focus on the target.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: If you have advantage on your attack, you may add a d4 to your attack roll. If you have disadvantage on your attack, as an ability action, you may roll your choice of athletics or acrobatics check to negate the disadvantage. The DC is equal to your target’s AC.

Dueling Blades.Name: Sword Breaker
Dueling Blades.Description: A short weapon with notches on its spine, designed to catch, disarm, and in extreme cases, break the enemy’s weapon. The master can disarm in an instant, and with another weapon, possibly break the enemy’s sword.
Dueling Blades.Master Ability: When you deflect, you can also force your enemy to succeed on your choice of an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw or be disarmed. If your disarm attack is a critical hit, your enemy’s mundane weapon is broken and unusable.

Flails and Whips.Name: Double Flail
Flails and Whips.Description: Two flail heads, each with a separate chain attached to a single handle, whether they are attached at opposing ends, or attached at the same end. The Double flail is a difficult weapon to use effectively, and only the master really gets use out of individual heads, turning a potential miss into a new opportunity.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: When you suffer disadvantage but one dice would have hit, you deal 1 of the weapon’s damage dice plus half of your weapon ability modifier, even though this still counts as a miss. If you have advantage and both dice hit, add your weapon ability modifier twice to the damage total.

Flails and Whips.Name: Light Flail
Flails and Whips.Description: The familiar 2lb spiked ball at the end of a length of chain, attached to a short iron or wooden haft usually similar in length to a handaxe. The light flail sees lightning fast attacks turned into a great boon for the master, carrying the weapons speed and momentum into another attack if they miss.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: You may reroll any attack you miss, but must take the new result.

Flails and Whips.Name: Heavy Flail
Flails and Whips.Description: A large spiked metal bar attached to a long handle, allowing one or two handed usage. The massive head and lengthy chain put it in the same sphere of war as the warhammer and battle axe. A master’s binding and tripping attacks still harm their target if the enemy resists the maneuver.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: If your target successfully saves against your weapon DC, you can make an attack as part of the same action.

Flails and Whips.Name: Pole Flail
Flails and Whips.Description: A pole weapon with a spiked bar of the heavy flail at the end of a chain. The master learns to bind and wrap opponents, disrupting their footwork to allow their own free movement.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: When you make a melee attack against a creature, you don’t provoke opportunity attacks from that creature for the rest of the turn.

Flails and Whips.Name: Meteor Hammer
Flails and Whips.Description: A small weight attached to a rope or chain, used like a rope dart to make circular and explosive lunging attacks. A master can twirl the weapon around them with varying angles to strike any foe who might get near.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: As a reaction you can enter a readied stance. Until the start of your next turn, you may make an attack against any creature that enters your reach, and doing so does not use your reaction.

Flails and Whips.Name: Nunchaku
Flails and Whips.Description: The nunchaku is two rods bound by a rope or chain. By whipping around the body, a master can make lightning fast attacks to wield it like a Double Ended weapon.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: You can use the Double Ended property one handed. Dual wielding two nunchaku, you can attack twice with Double Ended.

Flails and Whips.Name: Trisectional Staff
Flails and Whips.Description: A quarterstaff cut into three sections, each connected with a small length of chain or rope. A master uses this weapon’s double hinges to strike in unpredictable ways, tripping or entangling with either end of the weapon.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: Your Disarm, Entangle, and Trip attacks deal bludgeoning damage equal to your 1.5 times your weapon ability modifier.

Flails and Whips.Name: Whip
Flails and Whips.Description: The whip is treated as a melee weapon with 15ft reach. You can use a whip to grasp unattended small objects, or any reasonable handhold within range and if possible, you can pull the object to you. A whip master treats their whips as extensions of their hands.
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: When you disarm any creature, you choose to place the item anywhere in your reach, or use your reaction to catch it. An item in your reach that can be grabbed with the whip can be placed anywhere else in your reach.

Flails and Whips.Name: Whip Sword (Sword Form)
Flails and Whips.Description:
A whip sword can be either a sword or a bladed whip. As an ability action, you change between the forms of your weapon. As a sword, it is similar to a longsword. As a whip, it gains reach, utility, and a target entangled by you takes your weapon’s damage. A master can quickly change between forms as needed to attack enemies near their entangled prey.
The Sword and Whip forms of this weapon are split into two different entries within this table
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: You may change between weapon forms freely. Additionally, when you hit with this weapon, you can choose to deal only your weapon ability modifier in damage and automatically entangle your enemy by changing to its whip profile.

Flails and Whips.Name: Whip Sword (Whip Form)
Flails and Whips.Description:
A whip sword can be either a sword or a bladed whip. As an ability action, you change between the forms of your weapon. As a sword, it is similar to a longsword. As a whip, it gains reach, utility, and a target entangled by you takes your weapon’s damage. A master can quickly change between forms as needed to attack enemies near their entangled prey.
The Sword and Whip forms of this weapon are split into two different entries within this table
Flails and Whips.Master Ability: While an enemy is entangled, you can still attack it or any target within 5ft of it.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Light Hammer
Hammers and Picks.Description: A short-handled hammer about the size of a handaxe and just as balanced for throwing. While a mace may shred armor, a hammer delivers precise blows that weaken the enemy, and a master can disorient the opponent for follow up attacks.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: When you score a critical hit, the enemy suffers a 1d6 penalty to their next skill check.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Light Pick
Hammers and Picks.Description: A long, thin pick, mounted to a short haft, capable of precise, targeted piercing attacks that punch through armor with ease. Though not as stout as a war pick, the light pick allows more agile maneuvers, as well as balanced throwing. A master looks for the perfect opening, placing the pick into soft targets or between plates where armor is lacking.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: Your Penetrate property ignores 3/4 of your target’s armor bonus to their Armor Class.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Lucerne
Hammers and Picks.Description: A pole mounted, pronged hammer head for crushing blows on one side and a vicious hooking spike head for piercing and peeling armor on the other. The long haft allows the wielder to put devastating force behind the blows of this weapon. Lucerne masters swing at angles which force their enemies to choose between sacrificing equipment or flesh.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: If your enemy succeeds on the save from your Trip attack, they instead take normal weapon damage.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Maul
Hammers and Picks.Description: A massive weapon near the size of a greataxe with an immensely weighted head, the maul can send foes staggering from even attempting to block such a massive weapon. Mauls always gain advantage when rolling an attack to destroy an object. The master finds the best ways to bully their opponents with the weight of this massive weapon.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: Your knockbacks move a target 10ft in a direction of your choosing. Creatures one size category larger than you do not gain advantage on the save, and you may attempt to knockback creatures two size categories larger, though they gain advantage on the save. Creatures three size categories larger than you are immune as usual.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Stiletto
Hammers and Picks.Description: A thin, round spike with a thin point and round cross section make it perfect for fitting between or outright puncturing through metal plates or rings. A master employs a host of grappling techniques as follow ups to their initial attacks.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: When your enemy is entangled, you can use your ability action to attempt a shove.

Hammers and Picks.Name: Wall Pick
Hammers and Picks.Description: Similar in size to the light pick, with a longer, hooked spike to aid in climbing. In combat, the hook is used to grapple or disarm enemies while still able to puncture and pierce armor. A wall pick gives you advantage on climb checks and you can climb onto creatures any size category bigger than you. The master can grapple a foe as easily as they latch onto a wall.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: If your entangle attack misses, you can reroll the attack once but must take the new roll. If you roll a critical hit, your enemy is restrained and grappled.

Hammers and Picks.Name: War Hammer
Hammers and Picks.Description: Historically a lightweight, long-handled weapon around 3ft-4ft in length, designed to damage armored enemies. The small, pronged hammer head is often backed with a military pick or different style of face. A master of the warhammer carries momentum into each attack to send foes reeling.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: If you move at least 10ft in a straight line before your attack, your attack ignores an additional 1 AC if wielding it one handed, or 2 AC if two handing your war hammer. On a critical hit, your weapon damages the target’s armor, permanently decreasing the armor class until the armor is repaired by Tinkers' or Smith's Tools.

Hammers and Picks.Name: War Pick
Hammers and Picks.Description: A weaponized miner’s pick, famously invented by militant mountain dwarves, refined worldwide for use against armored infantries. The pick comes in many forms but is usually a battle axe sized weapon with a reinforced spike on one end, and a narrow hammer opposite the spike. The master can strike vital areas, puncturing deeply to bleed the target out over time.
Hammers and Picks.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit your enemy begins to bleed. Roll a d10. At the start of its turn, the target takes this value as piercing damage, and takes 1 less each subsequent turn until 0 piercing damage. This damage stops if they receive any healing, or they spend an action to staunch the bleeding. If a target is affected by this bleeding damage, an additional critical hit will increase the bleed damage by your roll of a d10. It is up to your LM if your target is capable of bleeding.

Polearms.Name: Bladed Staff
Polearms.Description: A 6’ staff weapon with a sword on each end, usually straight, but curved varieties exist. A bladed staff can be used to great effect, creating space around the wielder in a skirmish, or used as an effective spear with a wicked butt end. The master is able to attack as quickly with two blades as others are with only one, in lightning rapid fire strikes that take full advantage of the weapon’s reach.
Polearms.Master Ability: When you use the double ended property, you do not need to be within 5ft of your target.

Polearms.Name: Glaive
Polearms.Description: Perhaps the simplest of the polearms, a glaive is a short sword blade mounted on a long pole, used like a spear or a greatsword, the wide, sweeping slashes become useful for dealing with enemies much bigger than the wielder. While originally designed to be used by infantry against cavalry, in the hands of a master, a glaive is quite effective as a giant killer.
Polearms.Master Ability: Against creatures of category size Large and larger, your damage is 3d6 instead of 2d6

Polearms.Name: Guisarme
Polearms.Description: A sharpened and sturdy pruning hook, developed as a peasant weapon from modifying a farm tool. The curved hook of the blade allows the guisarme to be used as a tripping weapon or to pull foes from the saddle. A guisarme is a favorite of common militias who will face cavalry in battle, as the master can pull a knight from the saddle with relative ease.
Polearms.Master Ability: Your trip attacks impose disadvantage to saving throws made to resist them and if you succeed against a mounted enemy, it is automatically pulled from its mount to prone.

Polearms.Name: Lajatang
Polearms.Description: A rare and unusual double ended weapon, consisting of a 3-5ft shaft and a crescent blade fitted at each end, with the points of the crescents pointing away from the haft of the weapon, giving it essentially 2 outward facing spear points on each end. Lajatang masters are extremely rare, but are a whirling dervish of crescent blades and points, dangerous from all sides.
Polearms.Master Ability: On your turn, you can spend your reaction to enter a Defensive Stance, negating any flanking bonus or ability any enemy might have for flanking you or having the enemy’s ally near you, such as pack tactics or sneak attack. You may use Double Ended twice on your turn, but your second attack must be against a different target than your first.

Polearms.Name: Partisan
Polearms.Description: Much like a Glaive design, this pole weapon is essentially a shortsword blade mounted to a long haft, but keeps a wide cross guard at the base of the blade, trading sweeping cuts for defensive guards. The master Partisan uses the guard of their weapon like a shield at distance, and can even use it to protect allies.
Polearms.Master Ability: You have +1 weapon AC. When an enemy lands an attack on an ally within your range, you may use your reaction to force the enemy to reroll the attack.

Polearms.Name: War Scythe
Polearms.Description: Whether mounted horizontally like a traditional farming implement, or mounted vertically like a glaive, a war scythe has its roots in a peasant militia looking to arm itself in times of war. A scythe in the right hands can be useful in combat, though it takes a practiced master to be truly effective. The master uses the scythe’s reaping motion to deal horrible slashing wounds to the foes they trip in combat.
Polearms.Master Ability: Your trip attacks deal full weapon damage, and if you knock a creature prone, its speed is reduced by half. At the end of its turn, the enemy can attempt a Constitution check, ending the effect on a success.

Spears.Name: Godendag
Spears.Description: A short spear with a heavy ball socket to hold the spear point, making use of sweeping bludgeons and weighted piercing attacks. The master makes full use of the added weight for powerful blows that set their enemy off balance.
Spears.Master Ability: If you score a critical hit, the next attack against this target gains advantage.

Spears.Name: Harpoon
Spears.Description:
A barbed throwing spear with a welded ring, attached to a length of rope or chain so the target or harpoon can be retrieved. This weapon comes with 50ft of silk rope, which is reflected in the cost and weight. A master of the harpoon impales with ease and can swiftly reel in a harpooned prey.
On a hit, your enemy must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be impaled, while a critical hit always impales.
Spears.Master Ability: You drag an enemy toward you up to 20 feet, and your target suffers disadvantage to Athletics while while it is impaled.

Spears.Name: Javelin
Spears.Description: A light throwing spear balanced for flight but sturdy enough as a simple spear. A master can make an Olympian throw, puncturing shields so deeply, the enemy must pry the remnants out before it can be of any use in combat.
Spears.Master Ability: When you score a critical, the target suffers a -2 AC penalty. On its turn an enemy can use an action to succeed on an Athletics check to pry the javelin free, destroying it in the process.

Spears.Name: Lance
Spears.Description: Designed to unseat mounted enemies from the saddle, while on foot a lance imposes disadvantage against targets within 5ft, but while mounted gains One Handed and Penetrate. Masters leverage their mount’s strength, allowing for devastating blows that knock enemies to the ground.
Spears.Master Ability: You may attempt a Shove as an ability action. While mounted, after you successfully hit a target, you can attempt a shove as part of the same attack and gain advantage in the roll. Additionally, you no longer suffer disadvantage to attack rolls when you use this weapon on foot.

Spears.Name: Pike
Spears.Description: An 8-12 ft polearm designed for soldiers in a phalanx against an opposing line. A master with the pike fights as a phalanx soldier, striking so deftly they can stop a charging foe.
Spears.Master Ability: You ignore half cover. Additionally, if you land an attack on a target more than 5ft away, it cannot move closer to you until the end of its next turn.

Spears.Name: Ravenbeak
Spears.Description: This pike has a crescent blade on the side of the tip used to hook or slash. The added hook reduces the spear’s penetration, but its utility makes up the difference. The master can redirect attacks and disarm with ease.
Spears.Master Ability: If an enemy misses you with a melee attack, you can cause it to target a creature of your choosing within its reach with that same attack roll.

Spears.Name: Trident
Spears.Description: The war trident has sharpened, thicker tines and is used as an axe just as often as a spear. The master can trap, bind and disarm enemies with ease.
Spears.Master Ability: You can deflect attacks against any target in reach. When you wield a trident with two hands, your enemy must succeed on a Reflex check or be disarmed when you deflect.

Spears.Name: War Spear
Spears.Description: A short, throw-balanced, banded spear with a hefty counterweight for one handed control or a two handed bludgeon. A master is a true war fighter, using spear techniques as ancient as the armies that employed them.
Spears.Master Ability: If you use this weapon one handed, you can use Double Ended as if you were using it with two. In two hands, you deal an additional d4 damage each time you hit with the main melee attack.

Spears.Name: Winged Spear
Spears.Description: Small protrusions on either side of the spear head prevents a skewered target from closing on its wielder. A master keeps foes at bay while controlling their position.
Spears.Master Ability: If you land an attack, you can move your target 5ft in a direction of your choice, and that target can’t move closer to you until the end of its next turn.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Bolas
Throwing Weapons.Description:
A pair of weights connected to a reinforced cord or chain to bind a target’s limbs. The master bolo accurately targets the legs to bind and trip in one attack.
A normal bolas has an 15AC, 2HP and is immune to bludgeoning damage, but more sturdy versions may exist. When your enemy escapes from or reduces the bolas to 0hp, it is destroyed.
Bolas are a type of weapon that uses the Entangle property even if no one is holding the weapon.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: When your entangle attack hits, the target must succeed on the save or become prone and restrained.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Boomerang
Throwing Weapons.Description: A hooked wing, sharpened on the inner curve and used like a cudgel. The master can curve its flight path to hit more than one target with a powerful throw.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: Once on your turn, you can choose two targets within 40ft to attack with the same attack.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Chakram
Throwing Weapons.Description: A sharpened discus or ring, sturdy enough to be used in melee. Dangerous from all angles, the master uses any opening as an opportunity for a quick throw or slash.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: If a creature misses you with an attack, as a reaction you can attack that creature.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Dart
Throwing Weapons.Description: A short rod fletched like an arrow with a weighted tip. A master pins targets with precision aimed at clothing.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: You can choose to deal no damage on hit and pin the enemy to an adjacent wall or obstacle causing your enemy to be restrained. The escape DC is your weapon DC.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Kunai
Throwing Weapons.Description: A small, dagger-like tool of Japanese origin derived from a masonry trowel. Its ring pommel and wide design allow for unique utility with rope, and in the hands of a master, the heavier design allows for deflections mid-flight.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: You can use your deflect property within your normal thrown range, and for any creature of your choice.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Net
Throwing Weapons.Description: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until freed. It has no effect on creatures that are formless or Huge or larger. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC10) ends the restrained condition and destroys the net. Masters can toss the net in a way that tangles it around their prey, making it much harder to escape.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: The net’s AC is increased by 10. If you have advantage on an entangle attack, your target has disadvantage on the check made to escape.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Throwing Knife
Throwing Weapons.Description: Small, balanced knives with a broad piercing tip and sharpened pommel, no longer than 4”-6”. Easily hidden, these blades offer more range than throwing stars due to the higher weighted pommel. A master has perfected the art of quick throws at their enemy’s hands or arms as they swing a weapon, causing the knife to interfere with their attack.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: You can choose to deal only your weapon ability modifier in damage, but force your target to succeed on a Reflex check or lose its reaction and suffer disadvantage on its next attack roll.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Throwing Shot
Throwing Weapons.Description: Though not strictly their invention, the technique to throw an iron ball in combat was pioneered by the Orcs. Not many can stand up to the heavy iron in flight. A master is deadly accurate with the shot and is able to target an enemy’s head to stun if they have an advantage. A creature with Strength less than 13 cannot wield a shot at all.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: If you have advantage and both dice would have hit, or if you score a critical hit, your enemy must succeed on a Constitution check or be stunned until the end of its next turn. If you have disadvantage but one dice would have hit, deal your weapon ability modifier in damage, though this still counts as a miss.

Throwing Weapons.Name: Throwing Star
Throwing Weapons.Description: Star shaped metal disks made to be palmed together and thrown as a pepper of smaller strikes to disable an enemy before a followup attack. The flat, small design of these weapons allows many to be palmed at once and thrown all together. A master has the capability to dance in a quick circle, throwing stars at all foes around them.
Throwing Weapons.Master Ability: As an action, you can make a single attack against all targets of your choice within 20 ft of you. You must have enough throwing stars to attack each target.

Natural Weapons.Name: Bite
Natural Weapons.Description: If a creature is two size categories bigger than the creature it is biting, the bite grapples on hit. This listing can be used for any other attack which originates from the mouth, e.g mandibles, beaks, maw, etc. No hands are needed to use this weapon.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: When you successfully entangle your target you also deal your full weapon damage. While your enemy is entangled, it suffers disadvantage to checks made to escape your grapple.

Natural Weapons.Name: Claws
Natural Weapons.Description: Claws adorn the hands of most predators and can be used in the takedown and grapple of prey. Claw asters use their grappling as offensive tools in this egard. This listing can be used for any other natural weapons which are at the end of an appendage, e.g. pincers, talons, impale, etc. If your claws are retractable, you gain the Conceal property.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: If you succeed in a grapple contest to impose or escape the grappled condition, you deal your weapon’s damage to your target.

Natural Weapons.Name: Horns
Natural Weapons.Description: Horns are among the strongest organic materials and can easily punch through tough hide and thick armor. This listing can be used for any attack which is of a similar source, e.g. spike, gore, ram, etc. No hands are needed to use this weapon.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: When you move at least 20 feet, you can make one melee attack with your horns as an ability action. If this attack hits, it counts as a critical hit.

Natural Weapons.Name: Slam
Natural Weapons.Description: Creatures with bulk or lacking in obvious teeth and claws can use their weight against a target. A creature two size categories larger than its target always applies the stagger property to each attack. This listing can be used for any other blunt attack, e.g. hooves, fist, stomp, etc. No hands are needed to use this weapon.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: If you move at least 20ft straight toward an enemy and land a slam attack in the same turn, that enemy must succeed on an Athletics check or be knocked prone and you can make an additional slam attack as an ability action.

Natural Weapons.Name: Tail
Natural Weapons.Description: Most tails are not prehensile, but a tail can be used for a surprise swipe either at an enemy’s feet or an off angle at their sword hand, possibly disarming them. This listing can be used for any other long, tail-like attack, e.g. pseudopod, tentacle, tendril, etc. No hands are needed to use this weapon.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: When you hit with a normal attack, your target must succeed on a Reflex check or be knocked prone.

Natural Weapons.Name: Wings
Natural Weapons.Description: While most wings are too delicate to be used as a weapon, they can be used in an emergency for defensive purposes. If your wings have no damage listing, they use deflect d6, otherwise using the damage listed for the attack. No hands are needed to use this weapon.

Untrained.Damage: A creature with a natural weapon will always have at least a +2 (Trained) ability modifier with their Natural Weapons.

Trained.Damage: Defined in the ability that gives the natural weapon

Experienced.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Experienced (for example, from 1d4 to 1d6).

Master.Damage: Increases by 1 dice size at Master (for example, from 1d6 to 1d8).

Natural Weapons.Master Ability: As an action, you can flap your wings and create a powerful gust of wind. All creatures in a 15ft cone in front of you must succeed on an Athletics or Reflex Saving Throw or be your choice of pushed back 5ft or prone.
